text: Throughout the pandemic, technology has been saving our jobs and our sanity – but in Barcelona the lockdowns have led to the revival of one of humanity’s simplest and most enduring inventions: the book. The city’s booksellers are reporting a boom in sales and, against all odds, new bookshops have opened. The latest of the new crop of shops is the Llibreria Byron, launched by the small academic publisher Huygens, which opened in November in the Sant Antoni area of the city. “We’d been planning this for three years and were set to open in April, but that obviously wasn’t possible,” said Mariana Sarrias, the shop’s co-owner. “After nine months of uncertainty and with everything that, as a small business, we had invested, it was very worrying,” she said, adding that they chose the name Byron “because he was romantic and also quite transgressive”. “The day we finally opened in November there was a queue of people waiting to get in. There wasn’t room for everyone. It was really quite moving. Since then people come every day. I don’t know if it’s out of solidarity or because the bookshop is something the barrio [suburb] lacked.” “The pandemic has made people aware of the need to support their local bookshop,” said Maria Carme Ferrer, president of the Catalan booksellers’ association. “Bookshops are local cultural centres.” Sarrias says that as publishers they had already noticed an increase in orders during lockdown. “Maybe people ran out of things to watch on Netflix,” she said, or perhaps, as they were forced into isolation, people realised that books are good company. And yet only recently the book business looked doomed. In 2013 the Catalonia bookshop, a magnet for the city’s readers since 1924, was forced to close and was replaced by a McDonald’s. That same year Canuda, the labyrinthine secondhand bookshop that was the inspiration behind the “cemetery of forgotten books” in Carlos Ruiz Zafón’s bestselling The Shadow of the Wind, also went out of business. It is now a branch of fashion chain Mango.
a2_text:
During the pandemic, technology helped us a lot. It helped us keep our jobs and feel better. But in Barcelona, the lockdowns did something else. They helped books become popular again. Books are a very old and simple invention.

Bookshops in Barcelona are selling many books. Some new bookshops have even opened. One new shop is called Llibreria Byron. It was started by a small company called Huygens. The shop opened in November in Sant Antoni.

Mariana Sarrias owns the shop with someone else. She said they planned to open in April. But they could not because of the pandemic. They waited for nine months. They were worried because they had spent a lot of money. They named the shop Byron after a writer. He was romantic and different.

When they opened in November, many people were waiting. The shop was full. Mariana said it was very emotional. People come to the shop every day. She does not know why. Maybe people want to help them. Or maybe the area needed a bookshop.

Maria Carme Ferrer is the head of the booksellers' group. She said people want to help local bookshops because of the pandemic. She thinks bookshops are important places for culture.

Mariana said her company sold more books during the lockdown. Maybe people were bored of watching TV. Or maybe people felt lonely and books were good friends.

A few years ago, bookshops were not doing well. In 2013, a famous bookshop called Catalonia closed. It had been open since 1924. A McDonald’s is there now. In the same year, another bookshop called Canuda closed. It was a big, old shop. It inspired a book called "The Shadow of the Wind." Now a clothing store is in that place. The clothing store is called Mango.

text: Perhaps this sudden revival is only to be expected in a city that is the capital of the Spanish publishing trade and where the Catalans’ love of books is celebrated every year on 23 April, birthday of the patron saint, Sant Jordi (St George), and coincidentally Shakespeare’s birthday. On this day people exchange gifts of books and roses and the streets are lined with impromptu book stalls. The pandemic meant that Sant Jordi was effectively cancelled this year and it’s likely to be a small-scale affair in 2021, according to Lluís Morral, manager of Laie, perhaps the city’s best-loved bookshop. Morral says sales have definitely increased during lockdown, especially among the classics rather than recent bestsellers. “A lot of people have come back to reading and they aren’t looking for the latest publication but are more catching up on books they meant to read a few years ago,” he said. “A lot of people buy books on Sant Jordi but don’t read them. Now they realise they have all these books at home and they’ve started reading them.” He agrees with Sarrias that isolation has led people to discover – or remember – that books are very companionable. “I can’t speak for everyone, but among my acquaintances a lot of people reached saturation point watching TV series,” Morral said. Both Laie and Byron are bookshop-cafes with quiet spaces for reading, a much-needed refuge in what is officially Europe’s noisiest city. Two other new outlets, Ona, which sells books only in Catalan, and Finestres, due to open in the spring, have also set themselves up as places to meet and read as well as to buy books. Both have been financed by local philanthropists and, while he wishes them well, Morral knows that like all bookshops these relative minnows will have a battle on their hands to compete with Amazon. “What we [independent bookshops] can offer is a personal service and an understanding of what book you’ve bought and what you might also enjoy, rather than have an algorithm tell you what to read next,” he said.
a2_text:
Maybe this comes as no surprise. This city is the capital of Spanish books. The people of Catalonia love books. Every year, on April 23, they celebrate this love. April 23 is the birthday of Sant Jordi (Saint George). It is also Shakespeare's birthday!

On this day, people give books and roses to each other. The streets have many small book shops for this day. This year, the virus stopped the Sant Jordi celebration. It will probably be small in 2021. This is according to Lluís Morral. He is the manager of Laie. Laie is a very popular bookshop in the city.

Morral says that book sales have gone up. This happened when people stayed home. People are buying old, famous books. They are not buying the newest books. He said that many people are reading again. They want to read books they planned to read before.

He said people buy books on Sant Jordi. But they do not read them. Now, they know they have books at home. So they are reading them. He agrees with Sarrias. He thinks staying at home made people read. They saw that books are good friends.

Morral said that many people got tired of watching TV. Laie and Byron are bookshops with cafes. They have quiet places for reading. This is important because this city is very loud. It is the loudest city in Europe!

Two new shops are opening. Ona sells books in the Catalan language. Finestres will open soon. These shops want to be places to meet and read. People can also buy books there. Rich people from the city helped to pay for these shops. Morral hopes they do well.

But he knows it will be hard. All small bookshops must compete with Amazon. Amazon is a big online store. Morral said that small bookshops can help people more. They can understand what books you like. They can suggest books you might enjoy. Amazon only uses a computer to tell you what to read.

text: The French government has been accused of pandering to anti-vaxxers after figures showed that only a few hundred people had received a jab several days after the country’s vaccine programme began. Health officials said France is setting out for “a marathon, not a sprint” and that they are going slowly, in part, because of high levels of public scepticism about the vaccine. Only around 40% of people in France have said they are willing to be vaccinated, according to a recent poll. The figure has dropped since October, when just over half of French people said they were happy to be vaccinated. Willingness to have the vaccine is reportedly 77% in Britain and 69% in the US. France started administering the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine on Sunday, beginning with staff and residents in care homes and those considered at risk of developing severe symptoms of the virus. It is the only country insisting that those offered the vaccine give their written consent after being informed of possible contraindications. However, fewer than 100 people were vaccinated in the first three days. By Wednesday evening, only 332 people had received the vaccine, according to health ministry officials. The ministry has said the aim is to vaccinate 1 million elderly and at-risk people in January, requiring more than 31,200 vaccinations every day. The health minister, Olivier Véran, admitted that France was vaccinating more slowly than other countries and suggested this was a deliberate policy to enable an information campaign rather than the result of a lack of vaccines or a logistical failure. “We have the same number of vaccine doses as our German neighbours, we have the same aims and we will have the same results,” Véran told French television. “It’s taking a while to get off the ground … I don’t confuse speed with haste,” he added. The president, Emmanuel Macron, and ministers have promised the vaccine will not be obligatory and officials have assured the public there will be no list compiled of those who refuse to have the Covid-19 jab. However, Macron said people should be guided by “reason and science”. “The vaccine is not obligatory. Have confidence in our scientists and doctors,” he said.
a2_text:
The government of France is getting criticism. Some people think they are trying to please people who do not want the vaccine.

The vaccine program started in France a few days ago. But not many people have had the vaccine.

Health workers in France say they are going slowly. They say it is a long race, not a fast one.

One reason they are going slowly is that many people in France do not trust the vaccine.

A survey said that only 40% of people in France want to get the vaccine. This number was higher in October. Then, more than half of the people in France wanted the vaccine.

In Britain, 77% of people want the vaccine. In the United States, 69% of people want it.

France started giving the vaccine on Sunday. It is the Pfizer/BioNTech vaccine. The first people to get it were workers and people living in care homes. They also gave it to people who are more likely to get very sick.

France is the only country that wants people to write down that they agree to get the vaccine. They must agree after someone tells them about possible problems.

But in the first three days, not many people got the vaccine. Less than 100 people got it. By Wednesday evening, 332 people had the vaccine. This information comes from health officials.

The health ministry wants to give the vaccine to one million older people and people at risk in January. They need to give more than 31,200 vaccines every day to do this.

The health minister, Olivier Véran, said France is giving the vaccine slower than other countries. He said this is on purpose. He wants to give people information about the vaccine first. He said it is not because they do not have enough vaccines or have problems getting them to people.

Véran said that France has the same amount of vaccine as Germany. He said they have the same goals and will have the same results.

He also said that it takes time to start. He said that going fast is not the same as rushing.

The president, Emmanuel Macron, and his ministers said the vaccine is not required. They said they will not make a list of people who do not want the vaccine.

But Macron said people should listen to science. He said to trust the scientists and doctors.

text: In his new year address on Thursday, Macron vowed to avoid “unjustifiable delays” to vaccinations but also struck a defensive note, saying he would let “no one play with the safety” of the campaign. Axel Kahn, a leading geneticist and head of the National League Against Cancer, told Europe 1 radio that France’s vaccine strategy was wrong. “It is not suited to a situation that is so dangerous,” he said. Philippe Juvin, head of the casualty ward at the Georges-Pompidou hospital in Paris, agreed. “As an individual, I would like to be vaccinated to set an example and show people that we don’t die from the vaccine, we die from Covid. And when we don’t die, we can get severe forms of it that are very disabling,” Juvin told CNews television. Opposition leaders said the slowness of the vaccination programme made France the “dunce” of Europe. Damien Abad, leader of the centre-right opposition Les Républicains in the Assemblée Nationale, demanded an urgent meeting with the health minister. In a letter, other opposition critics wrote: “Mass vaccination is the ultimate means of seeing our country emerge from the damaging economic situation caused by the health crisis. Yet France is vaccinating 10,000 times slower than the UK.” They added: “France cannot be one of the last countries to get vaccinated and yet that’s the picture we’re facing today.” Alain Fischer, the government official overseeing France’s vaccination programme, told Europe 1 the country had chosen to prioritise the elderly and vulnerable, as opposed to health professionals, as in other countries. “There is no good or bad choice … These are small details that will seem ridiculous in two or three months,” he said. Critics say this hesitation is feeding conspiracy theories and anti-vaxxer sentiment. Nathan Peiffer-Smadja, an infection specialist at Paris’s Bichat hospital, said the scientific data was clear. “The vaccine is safe and efficient. Like many of my colleagues, I think we should be giving the vaccines quicker in order to control the epidemic more rapidly. At the rate we’re going, we’ll still be in lockdown in 2022,” he tweeted.
a2_text:
Here's the text rewritten in CEFR A2 level English:

President Macron spoke on Thursday. It was his speech for the new year. He said vaccinations must not take too long. But he also said that safety is most important. He said he will not let anyone risk safety during vaccinations.

Axel Kahn is a doctor. He studies genes. He is also the head of a group against cancer. He said France's plan for vaccines is not good. He said it is not right for a dangerous situation.

Philippe Juvin works at a hospital in Paris. He is in charge of the emergency room. He said he wants to get the vaccine. He wants to show people it is safe. He wants people to know that people die from COVID. COVID can also make people very sick for a long time.

Other leaders in France are not happy. They said France is vaccinating people too slowly. They said France is the worst in Europe for vaccinations.

Damien Abad is a leader in the government. He wants to talk to the health minister soon.

Other leaders wrote a letter. They said vaccines are very important. They said vaccines will help France's economy. The economy is bad because of the virus. They said France is vaccinating much slower than the UK. They said France cannot be one of the last countries to give vaccines. But that is happening now.

Alain Fischer is in charge of the vaccine program in France. He said France is giving vaccines to old and sick people first. Other countries are giving vaccines to doctors and nurses first. He said both ways are okay. He said people will not remember the small differences in a few months.

Some people think the slow start is bad. They think it makes people not trust the vaccine. They think it makes people believe wrong ideas about the vaccine.

Nathan Peiffer-Smadja is a doctor who studies infections. He said the vaccine is safe and works well. He thinks France should give vaccines faster. This will help stop the virus faster. He said if France continues slowly, they will still be in lockdown in 2022.

text: France reported 26,457 new confirmed cases on Wednesday in 24 hours, but attributed the rise to increased testing. There were 304 deaths in hospital. The number of positive tests remains low, at 2.9%.
a2_text:
Here's the rewritten text at CEFR A2 level:

France said they found many new cases of the virus on Wednesday. They found 26,457 new cases in one day. This is because they did more tests for the virus.

304 people died in the hospital.

Not many tests were positive. Only 2.9% of the tests showed the virus.

text: Officials in Gibraltar are making daily patrols of the territory’s Barbary macaque population amid fears that the iconic monkeys could be vulnerable to the coronavirus. The British overseas territory has been relatively spared by the virus, documenting about 1,500 confirmed cases and six deaths. But as governments around the world wrestle with how to keep the coronavirus at bay, authorities in the Rock are grappling with an additional worry: how to shield Europe’s only wild monkey population from the virus. “We knew it from day one,” said Mark Pizarro, the veterinary officer responsible for the care of Gibraltar’s macaque population. “It’s logical. You have a virus that lives in primates like us, then it’s going to always be a risk to other primates.” Earlier this year the government sought to crack down on interactions with the macaques, which rank among the territory’s top tourist attractions. A new law, passed in August, made it an offence to touch or interfere with the monkeys, adding to existing legislation that sets out hefty fines for feeding them. “Macaques are prone to succumb to human disease,” the government noted in a statement announcing the new law. “This has been seen in the past when our macaques have for example contracted hepatitis A.” Believed to have been living on the Rock since the Moorish occupation of the Iberian peninsula, local folklore has it that as long as the macaques roam Gibraltar, the territory will remain under British rule. Officials have at times gone to remarkable lengths to protect the population; during the second world war, Winston Churchill gave an order to bolster their dwindling numbers with macaques from north Africa. Today the population stands at about 220 macaques. Coronavirus tests carried out in recent months on four – all of which died of other causes, such as road traffic accidents – came back negative, reinforcing the government’s view that the virus poses only a mild risk to the macaques. But concerns grew again in November after Denmark announced plans to cull more than 15 million mink over fears that new mutations discovered in the animals could undermine the effectiveness of Covid-19 vaccines.
a2_text:
Here is the rewritten text at a CEFR A2 level:

People in Gibraltar are checking the monkeys every day. These monkeys are called Barbary macaques. They are worried that the monkeys could get the coronavirus.

Gibraltar is a British place near Spain. Not many people there have had the virus. About 1,500 people got sick, and six people died.

Governments all over the world are trying to stop the virus. In Gibraltar, people have another problem. They want to protect the monkeys from the virus. These monkeys are the only wild monkeys in Europe.

Mark Pizarro takes care of the monkeys. He said that it was always a worry. The virus can live in people like us. So, it can be dangerous for monkeys too.

Earlier this year, the government made new rules. They wanted to stop people from getting close to the monkeys. Many tourists like to see the monkeys.

In August, they made a new law. Now, it is against the law to touch the monkeys. It is also against the law to give them food. People can get big fines if they do.

The government said that monkeys can get sick from people's diseases. They said that the monkeys got hepatitis A before.

The monkeys have lived in Gibraltar for a long time. Some people say that as long as the monkeys are there, Gibraltar will be British.

People have done a lot to protect the monkeys. During the war, Winston Churchill told people to bring more monkeys from Africa. Now, there are about 220 monkeys.

Recently, they tested four monkeys for the virus. But the monkeys died because of other things, like car accidents. The tests were negative. The government thinks the virus is not a big danger to the monkeys.

But in November, people got worried again. Denmark said they would kill many mink animals. They were worried that the virus was changing in the mink. They thought the changes could make the vaccine not work well.

text: The Gibraltar government described the Danish announcement as “particularly worrying” given that it suggested that the macaques, should they contract the virus, could become a source of infection for humans and potentially pass on mutations that could jeopardise vaccination efforts. Pizarro said his team of six had been monitoring the macaques on a daily basis. So far they have seen little sign of infection. What their patrols have made clear, however, is that the pandemic – and specifically the resulting plunge in tourism – has been a boon to the macaques. “Their behaviour in a lot of cases has reverted to normal. They interact with themselves, they forage naturally, they spend more time grooming each other, there’s less aggression between the macaques,” said Pizarro. “So there is a lot of positive spin from decreased human contact.”
a2_text:
Here's the rewritten text at A2 level:

The government in Gibraltar is worried. Denmark said something about the monkeys. It is "very worrying" for the government.

Denmark said that the monkeys might get sick. They could get a virus. If the monkeys get the virus, they could give it to people. The virus could change in the monkeys. This could make the vaccine not work well.

Pizarro has a team. His team has six people. They watch the monkeys every day. They have not seen many sick monkeys yet.

The team sees that the monkeys are doing better. There are fewer tourists now because of the virus. This is good for the monkeys.

Pizarro said the monkeys are acting normal again. They play with each other. They look for food by themselves. They clean each other more. They fight less.

Pizarro said less people is good for the monkeys.

text: Jonathan Pollard, a former US Navy analyst who served three decades in prison for leaking thousands of classified documents to Israel, has arrived in Tel Aviv after being released from parole. Israel’s prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, greeted Pollard and his wife, Esther, as they walked down the steps from a private jet, footage distributed by the prime minister’s office showed. The couple, both Orthodox Jews, removed their masks and kissed the ground before greeting Netanyahu. “We are ecstatic to be home at last after 35 years,” said Pollard, who was born in the US but was granted Israeli citizenship during his imprisonment. “No one could be prouder of this country or this leader than we are.” After saying a Hebrew prayer of thanksgiving for the liberation of prisoners, Netanyahu presented Pollard, 66, with Israeli identification documents. “Welcome home,” the prime minister said. Having been arrested by FBI agents in 1985 after unsuccessfully seeking refuge at the Israeli embassy in Washington, Pollard was sentenced to life in prison in 1987. The initial shock between the US and its close ally, and Pollard’s continued imprisonment, has long strained relations between the two countries. Netanyahu has pushed for Pollard’s release for decades. During the leader’s first term in the late 1990s, Pollard was granted Israeli citizenship. However, repeated previous attempts to persuade US presidents to grant Pollard clemency have failed. Pollard’s release from parole last month was the latest in a series of gestures by the departing Trump administration towards Netanyahu’s government. In a phone call last month, Netanyahu said to Pollard: “When are we going to see you here? We’re waiting for you.” Pollard’s lawyer, Eliot Lauer, told the Times of Israel that his arrival was “a dream realised after 35 very difficult years”. The couple are expected to enter several days of quarantine, which is compulsory for all returning Israelis as a measure to guard against the spread of coronavirus.
a2_text:
Jonathan Pollard is in Israel now. He used to work for the US Navy. He gave secret papers to Israel. He was in prison for 30 years.

He was let out of prison. Then, he had to follow rules for some time. This time is called parole. Now, his parole is over. He went to Tel Aviv in Israel.

Benjamin Netanyahu is the leader of Israel. He met Jonathan and his wife, Esther. They came off a plane. The leader's office showed a video of this.

Jonathan and Esther are Jewish. They took off their masks. They kissed the ground. Then, they said hello to Netanyahu.

Jonathan said they were happy to be home. It took 35 years. He said he was proud of Israel and the leader. Jonathan was born in the US. But he became a citizen of Israel when he was in prison.

Netanyahu said a prayer. It was a prayer to thank God for letting prisoners go free. Then, Netanyahu gave Jonathan his Israeli papers. Netanyahu said, "Welcome home." Jonathan is 66 years old.

FBI agents caught Jonathan in 1985. He wanted to hide in the Israeli embassy. But he could not. In 1987, he was sent to prison for life.

The US and Israel are friends. But this made things difficult. Jonathan being in prison made things bad between the two countries. Netanyahu wanted Jonathan to be free for many years.

In the 1990s, Jonathan became a citizen of Israel. Netanyahu tried many times to ask the US president to let Jonathan go. But the president did not say yes.

Before leaving, the old US government let Jonathan out of parole. Netanyahu called Jonathan last month. He asked when he was coming to Israel. He said they were waiting for him.

Jonathan's lawyer said this was a dream come true. It was after 35 hard years.

Jonathan and Esther will stay inside for some days. This is because of the virus. Everyone coming to Israel must do this. This is to stop the virus from spreading.

text: Campaigners are calling for social housing providers to put lives above profits following an Observer report on a black tenant who was left homeless after a racist campaign by neighbours. Former social housing chiefs, Lord Victor Adebowale, Aman Dalvi, Lord Geoffrey Filkin and Barry Simons have signed an open letter to the National Housing Federation highlighting wider failings to protect victims of racial harassment. The letter demands an urgent review of social housing policy to ensure that perpetrators of racial harassment are evicted, or their victims rehoused as a priority. The group acted after reading of the plight of Laura Tate (not her real name) who has been homeless for five years after fleeing her flat following death threats. Her housing provider, London and Quadrant (L&Q), refused to evict her abusers, despite their convictions for racially aggravated harassment and public order offences, and it failed to rehouse Tate. Last week a judge awarded her £31,000 in compensation after she sued L&Q for negligence. The Observer had also reported the case of another black tenant who has spent two years in a women’s refuge after fleeing an abusive ex-partner. L&Q failed to rehouse her without concrete evidence that she was endangered. “These are not isolated cases,” said the Labour peer Lord Filkin. “Board members and managers have a fundamental duty to ensure that tenants can live peacefully in their homes; there is more they need to do to ensure this duty is fulfilled.” L&Q, which houses 250,000 people in more than 105,000 homes across the south-east, has promised an independent review on how it handles abuse cases following the Observer investigation. In a statement on its website it admitted that there were lessons to be learned and said that it has a zero-tolerance policy on discrimination of any kind. The National Housing Federation, which represents housing associations, said that it would be glad to meet the letter’s signatories to discuss reforms. “We know that as a sector we can and must do better,” said chief executive Kate Henderson.
a2_text:
People are asking for changes in social housing. Social housing should help people more than make money.

This comes after a report in the Observer newspaper. The report was about a Black woman. She became homeless because her neighbours were racist.

Some important people who used to work in social housing have written a letter. These people are Lord Victor Adebowale, Aman Dalvi, Lord Geoffrey Filkin, and Barry Simons. They sent the letter to the National Housing Federation.

The letter says that social housing is not doing enough to protect people from racism. The letter asks for a quick look at social housing rules. People who are racist should be moved out. Or, the people who are being hurt by racism should be moved to a new home first.

The group wrote the letter after reading about Laura Tate. This is not her real name. She has been homeless for five years. She left her flat because people were threatening to kill her.

Her housing company is called London and Quadrant (L&Q). L&Q did not move out the people who were hurting her. These people were found guilty of racism. L&Q also did not give Laura Tate a new home.

Last week, a judge gave her £31,000. This was because she sued L&Q for not helping her.

The Observer also wrote about another Black woman. She lived in a safe house for two years. She left her home because her ex-boyfriend was hurting her. L&Q did not give her a new home because she did not have enough proof that she was in danger.

Lord Filkin said that these problems happen often. He said that the people in charge of housing must make sure that people can live in peace. He said that they need to do more to make this happen.

L&Q is a big housing company. It has 105,000 homes for 250,000 people in the south-east of England. L&Q said that it will look at how it deals with abuse cases. This will be done by someone who is not working for L&Q.

L&Q said that it can learn from these problems. It also said that it does not allow any kind of racism.

The National Housing Federation helps housing companies. It said that it will meet with the people who wrote the letter. They will talk about how to make things better. Kate Henderson is in charge of the Federation. She said that they need to do more to help people.

text: “Last month we launched our Equality, Diversity and Inclusion Insight report, which provided evidence of the change we need to deliver. “This, and our new code of governance, emphasise the importance of housing association boards and staff reflecting the diversity of the communities they serve and ensuring the sector is always working to strengthen relationships with residents.”
a2_text:
Here is the text rewritten in CEFR A2 level English:

Last month, we started a new report. It is about Equality, Diversity, and Inclusion. The report shows the changes we need to make.

This report and our new rules are important. They say that housing groups must have different kinds of people. This means the people in charge and the workers. They should be like the people in the area.

We need to make sure our housing groups look like the areas they help. It is important for us to work well with the people who live in our houses. We want to make our relationships with them stronger.

text: The ruthless campaign by the Chinese government to extinguish all memories of the massacre at Tiananmen Square has now resulted in the removal of the sculpture from the campus of the University of Hong Kong (Outcry as memorial to Tiananmen Square victims removed from Hong Kong University, 23 December). Since many of the countless victims were students, it is appropriate for universities elsewhere to ensure that their bravery and martyrdom is not eradicated from history. University student unions in the UK, not least at those institutions with many Chinese students, should keep their memory alive by renaming their building or part of it. This is what several did following the murder by the authorities of the black South African anti-apartheid student activist Steve Biko. The Steve Biko Bar at Bradford University closed in 2005 but the student union building at Manchester University (which has the largest student union in the UK) is still named after him. No doubt the chancellor of Oxford University, Chris Patten – who was the last British governor of Hong Kong – will be sympathetic. There is also plenty of space for the erection of a memorial near the Chinese embassy in central London. Dr Peter van den Dungen Ex-Bradford University lecturer, Halifax, West Yorkshire • Have an opinion on anything you’ve read in the Guardian today? Please email us your letter and it will be considered for publication.
a2_text:
The Chinese government wants people to forget about the Tiananmen Square event. They took away a statue from a university in Hong Kong. The statue remembered people who died at Tiananmen Square. Many of these people were students.

Universities in other countries should remember these students. They should not let their story be forgotten. Student groups in the UK can help. Some universities have many Chinese students. They can rename a building to remember the students from Tiananmen Square.

They did this before for Steve Biko. He was a student who fought against apartheid in South Africa. The government killed him. Bradford University had a bar named after him. It closed. Manchester University has a building named after him. It is the biggest student building in the UK.

Chris Patten is the head of Oxford University. He was the last British leader of Hong Kong. He will probably understand.

There is also space for a statue in London. It could be near the Chinese embassy.

Dr. Peter van den Dungen used to teach at Bradford University. He lives in Halifax.

Do you have an opinion about the news? Write a letter to the newspaper. They might publish it.

text: Confused anti-vaccine protesters entered a test-and-trace centre in Milton Keynes on Wednesday, appearing to believe it was a coronavirus vaccine centre, where they were filmed shouting abuse at staff and appearing to steal equipment. Video shared on social media showed the group of several dozen activists, led by former Ukip candidate Jeff Wyatt, walking through the facility holding signs encouraging people not to get vaccinated and criticising the BBC. Wyatt, a former deputy leader of the far-right For Britain Movement, addressed crowds at a rally held before the storming of the Covid-19 testing site, where he claimed there are “millions” of like-minded anti-vaccine activists who have “woken up”. Piers Corbyn, a prominent anti-lockdown protester and brother of the former Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, could not be seen in the footage but was pictured attending other stops during the so-called Freedom Rally including an invasion of the Milton Keynes Theatre. Protesters were filmed walking towards the NHS test-and-trace centre while a man on a loudspeaker claims that it is where the “vaccine rollout” is taking place as activists walk by a sign that reads “Testing”. Other demonstrators are heard shouting “disgrace” and “shame on you” as staff appear to run away and take shelter in offices. In several videos, a woman is seen unfurling a sign that reads “Reclaim NHS, End Jab” in one of the cabins before taking a large box containing what appears to be testing equipment and papers. She is seen unmasked and smiling at the cameras as she leaves the testing site. Thames Valley police said they were aware of an anti-vaccination protest that took place in central Milton Keynes on Wednesday afternoon. In a statement, the police said: “Where criminal offences have been disclosed, we will take swift action and bring offenders to justice. “If anyone has any information or wishes to report they can do by calling 101 or online quoting reference 604 29/12/2021.” The actions of the anti-vaccine protesters at the test-and-trace centre were described as “disgraceful” and faced widespread criticism by MPs.
a2_text:
Some people were protesting against vaccines. They were confused. They went to a test centre in Milton Keynes on Wednesday.

The test centre was not a vaccine centre. It was a place for coronavirus tests. But the protesters thought it was a vaccine centre.

They shouted at the people who worked there. They seemed to take some things from the centre. Someone filmed it and put it on social media.

A group of people walked through the test centre. They had signs. The signs said people should not get vaccines. The signs also criticized the BBC.

A man named Jeff Wyatt was with the group. He used to work for a political party. He spoke to the crowd before they went to the test centre. He said many people were against vaccines.

Piers Corbyn was also there. He is against lockdowns. He is the brother of Jeremy Corbyn. He was at other protests that day. The protests were called "Freedom Rally".

At the test centre, a man used a loudspeaker. He said vaccines were given there. But the sign said "Testing". Some protesters shouted bad words at the workers. The workers ran away to find a safe place.

A woman took a sign that said "Reclaim NHS, End Jab". She took a big box. It looked like it had test equipment and papers. She was not wearing a mask. She smiled at the cameras when she left.

The police know about the protest. They said they will take action if people broke the law. They asked people to call them if they had information.

People said the protesters' actions were bad. Many important people criticized them.

text: The local Tory MP Ben Everitt described the protesters as “dickheads” and urged anyone with information to contact police. Nick Thomas-Symonds, shadow secretary of state for international trade, described the protest as “dreadful”, at a site where “NHS staff are working over the festive season to help others”. He urged anyone with information to pass this on to Thames Valley police. Former health secretary Matt Hancock criticised the activists’ “appalling behaviour”. The Conservative MP for Rutland and Melton, Alicia Kearns, described the scenes as “shameful, self-aggrandising nonsense”. Helen Morgan, Liberal Democrat MP for North Shropshire, said the group’s actions were “totally unacceptable”. Government promised to act weeks ago but nothing as yet. Enough. It’s not free speech when 50% of debate in fear,” she said. Matthew Barber, police and crime commissioner for Thames Valley, said it was “appalling” to see the protest “escalate into something much uglier”. He added that he had spoken to Thames Valley police officers to discuss the police response on Wednesday evening, and said that “criminal offences will be investigated and appropriate action taken”. “All of the events of today will be reviewed to help plan for future protest events and ensure that colleagues in the NHS can continue their fantastic work in delivering the vaccine rollout,” he said. Joe Harrison, CEO of Milton Keynes University hospital, said: “I am very sorry and angry to see NHS colleagues at Milton Keynes Covid testing centre harassed and intimidated at their place of work. “Our staff having to deal with increasing aggression and violence for simply doing their job. It’s abhorrent, unacceptable and we will not stand for it.”
a2_text:

text: An Afghan former BBC journalist who managed to flee the Taliban has been stranded in a refugee camp for months because of delays to a resettlement scheme promised by the UK government. Mudassar Kadir* is the only one of 14 former BBC employees to have escaped Afghanistan since the Taliban took over in August. The other 13 remain in hiding in fear of their lives. Kadir, who also spent time working for the World Bank and the former Afghan government, had hoped he and his family could begin a new life after leaving Afghanistan, but since escaping in early October with the help of a US charity, Kadir and his wife and two young sons have been stuck in a refugee centre on the outskirts of Dubai. The Kadirs are grateful to the United Arab Emirates for the safe haven and are being well looked afte, but they are prevented from straying more than 100m from the building and the UAE will not accept asylum applications. Kadir is exasperated by the UK government’s repeated refusals in response to his request for help, and he still lives in fear of being sent back to Afghanistan where his work for the BBC has made him a target for the Taliban. “The UK should have a duty of care to me and my family. My life is at risk because I have worked for the BBC. The UK government knows this but they have done nothing to help me,” he said. “In the beginning we hoped that the UK would give me a visa, but now with each passing day my frustration grows.” Campaigners say the family’s predicament highlights the plight of thousands of Afghan immigrants caught in limbo, unable to return home for fear of persecution and prevented from travelling anywhere willing to grant them refugee status. The UK government has promised an Afghan citizens’ resettlement scheme (ACRS) to help as many as 5,000 people a year starting in January, alongside the existing more restrictive Afghanistan relocation and assistance policy (Arap). Kadir does not qualify for Arap, which has helped fewer than 400 people so far, and he is unable apply for ACRS because it is yet to open and when it does will only accept referrals for resettlements from NGOs. Campaigners fear the UK government is deliberately delaying the implementation of the scheme in an effort to reduce numbers.
a2_text:
Mudassar Kadir used to work for the BBC in Afghanistan. The BBC is a news company.
The Taliban took control of Afghanistan.
Mr. Kadir was scared and left Afghanistan.
He is now in a refugee camp. This is a place for people who had to leave their country.
He has been in the camp for many months.
The UK government said they would help him. But they have not yet helped him.
Mr. Kadir is one of 14 people who used to work for the BBC.
He is the only one who could leave Afghanistan.
The other 13 people are still hiding. They are afraid for their lives.
Mr. Kadir also worked for the World Bank and the old government of Afghanistan.
He wanted to start a new life with his family.
He left Afghanistan in October with help from a charity in the USA.
He is now in a refugee camp near Dubai. He is with his wife and two young sons.
The United Arab Emirates is keeping them safe. They are taking good care of them.
But they cannot go more than a little distance from the building.
The United Arab Emirates will not give them a home.
Mr. Kadir is sad because the UK government will not help him.
He is still afraid he will be sent back to Afghanistan.
The Taliban are angry at him because he worked for the BBC.
He said the UK should help him and his family. He said his life is in danger because he worked for the BBC. The UK knows this, but they are not helping.
He hoped the UK would give him a visa. Now he is more and more sad every day.
Some people are helping refugees. They say Mr. Kadir's situation is like many other Afghans.
These Afghans cannot go back home because they are afraid.
And they cannot go to other countries that would take them in.
The UK government said they would help Afghan people come to the UK. They called this plan the Afghan Citizens' Resettlement Scheme. It should start in January and help 5,000 people each year.
The UK also has another plan called Afghanistan Relocation and Assistance Policy. But it is harder to get help from this plan.
Mr. Kadir cannot get help from this plan. It has helped fewer than 400 people.
He cannot apply for the new plan because it is not open yet.
When it opens, only charities can ask for help for people.
Some people think the UK government is waiting to start the plan. They think the UK wants to help fewer people.

text: The Home Office denies this. “The ACRS is one of the most generous schemes in our country’s history and will give up to 20,000 further people at risk a new life in the UK,” a spokesperson said. “We continue to work at pace to open the scheme amid a complex and changing picture, working across government and with partners such as UNHCR to design the scheme.” It refuses to discuss individual cases. When asked to explain the delay, the Home Office said it was working on a system of “biometric enrolment” and eligibility checks to ensure those accepted did not pose a threat to national security. The Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants, which is representing Kadir and many others in the same predicament, says time is running out. Its interim chief executive, Minnie Rahman, said: “Three months ago, our government promised a ‘warm welcome’ to Afghan refugees but increasingly it seems that there’s precious little welcome to be found. “Like Kadir, many Afghans appear to have been shamefully abandoned by the British government, despite clear links to the UK. The resettlement scheme is still not open, family reunion routes are still extremely limited and our government seems unable to offer many who risked their lives working with us the refuge they so urgently need.” The National Union of Journalists has been lobbying the government to help secure visas for all Afghan former BBC staff, including one who survived an armed attack on a relative’s home in October. Its general secretary, Michelle Stanistreet, said: “Whilst progress on the resettlement process happens at a snail’s pace, journalists affected are living in fear and being forced into hiding. We need urgent and robust measures put in place to secure safe passage to the UK for all those Afghans at such high risk.” A spokesperson for the BBC said: “We have every sympathy with former staff, but we regret we are not in a position to extend our direct support to them.” Kadir said: “My hope is that the UK government will fulfil their commitment towards me and my family. But right now it seems no one is paying attention to my case. Since arriving in the UAE two months ago there has been zero progress.” * His name has been changed
a2_text:
The Home Office does not agree with this. A person from the Home Office said: "The ACRS is a very good plan. It will help 20,000 people who are in danger to live in the UK."

The person added: "We are working hard to start the plan. It is difficult because things are changing. We are working with other groups to make the plan."

This system will use "biometric enrolment" (fingerprints and photos). It will also check if people can join the plan. This is to make sure that people who come to the UK are not dangerous.

The Joint Council for the Welfare of Immigrants is helping Kadir and other people like him. They say there is not much time left. Minnie Rahman is the head of this group. She added: "Like Kadir, many Afghan people have been left alone by the British government. They have connections to the UK. The resettlement plan is not open yet. It is hard for families to come together. The government is not helping people who worked with them and are in danger."

The National Union of Journalists wants the government to help Afghan people who used to work for the BBC. One of them was attacked at home in October. Michelle Stanistreet is the head of this group. A person from the BBC said: "We feel bad for the people who used to work for us. But we cannot help them directly."

Kadir said: "I hope the UK government will keep their promise to me and my family. But right now, nobody is helping me. I came to the UAE two months ago, and nothing has changed."

text: On the brink of a new year, the world faces a daunting array of challenges: the resurgent Covid-19 pandemic, the climate emergency, the struggle between democracy and authoritarianism, humanitarian crises, mass migration, and trans-national terrorism. There is the risk of new inter-state conflicts, exacerbated by the breakdown of the rules-based international order, and the spread of lethal autonomous weapons. All in all, for most people on Earth – and a handful in space – 2022 will be another year of living dangerously. Middle East Events in the Middle East will make global headlines again in 2022 – but for positive as well as negative reasons. A cause for optimism is football’s World Cup, which kicks off in Qatar in November. It’s the first time an Arab or a Muslim country has hosted the tournament. It is expected to provide a major fillip for the Gulf region in terms of future business and tourism – and, possibly, more open, progressive forms of governance. But the choice of Qatar, overshadowed by allegations of corruption, was controversial from the start. Its human rights record will come under increased scrutiny. Its treatment of low-paid migrant workers is another flashpoint. The Guardian revealed that at least 6,500 workers have died since Qatar got the nod from Fifa in 2010, killed while building seven new stadiums, roads and hotels, and a new airport. Concerns will also persist about Qatar’s illiberal attitude to free speech and women’s and LGBTQ+ rights in a country where it remains dangerous to openly criticise the government and where homosexuality is illegal. But analysts suggest most fans will not focus on these issues, which could make Qatar 2022 the most successful example of “sports-washing” to date. More familiar subjects will otherwise dominate the regional agenda. Foremost is the question of whether Israel and/or the US will take new military and/or economic steps to curb Iran’s attempts, which Tehran denies, to acquire capability to build nuclear weapons. Israel has been threatening air strikes if slow-moving talks to revive the 2015 nuclear deal fail. Even football fans could not ignore a war in the Gulf.
a2_text:
The new year is coming. The world has many big problems.

*   The Covid-19 sickness is back.
*   The weather is changing in a bad way (climate change).
*   Some countries are free, and some are not (democracy vs. authoritarianism).
*   People need help in many places (humanitarian crises).
*   Many people are moving to new countries (mass migration).
*   Some groups are doing bad things in many countries (trans-national terrorism).

Countries might fight each other. It is harder for countries to work together. There are new weapons that can decide on their own who to attack (lethal autonomous weapons).

For most people, 2022 will be another hard year.

Something good and bad will happen in the Middle East.

The World Cup is in Qatar in November. Qatar is an Arab and Muslim country. It is the first time a country like this has the World Cup. This can bring more business and tourists to the Gulf area. It might also help the countries become more open.

But some people are not happy with Qatar having the World Cup. Some people think there was cheating. Qatar's rules about people are also not good. They treat workers from other countries badly.

The Guardian newspaper said that 6,500 workers have died in Qatar. They died while building stadiums, roads, hotels, and an airport for the World Cup.

Some people are worried that Qatar does not let people speak freely. They also worry about how Qatar treats women and LGBTQ+ people. It is not safe to speak against the government. Being gay is against the law.

But some people think that most fans will not care about these problems. They think the World Cup will make Qatar look good, even if it is not (sports-washing).

Other things will also be important in the Middle East. People will watch if Israel and the US will do something about Iran. Iran wants to make nuclear weapons, but they say they do not. Israel might attack Iran if talks do not work.

Even football fans will notice if there is a war in the Gulf.

text: Attention will focus on Turkey’s authoritarian president, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, whose neo-Islamist AKP party will mark 20 years in power in 2022. Erdoğan’s rule has grown increasingly oppressive at home, while his aggressive foreign policy, rows with the EU and US, on-off collusion with Russia over Syria and chronic economic mismanagement could have unpredictable consequences. Other hotspots are likely to be Lebanon – tottering on the verge of becoming a failed state like war-torn Yemen – and ever-chaotic Libya. Close attention should also be paid to Palestine, where the unpopular president, Mahmoud Abbas’s postponement of elections, Israeli settler violence and West Bank land-grabs, and the lack of an active peace process all loom large. Asia Pacific The eyes of the world will be on China at the beginning and the end of the year, and quite possibly in the intervening period as well. The Winter Olympics open in Beijing in February. But the crucial question, for sports fans, of who tops the medals table may be overshadowed by diplomatic boycotts by the US, UK and other countries in protest at China’s serial human rights abuses. They fear the Games may become a Chinese Communist party propaganda exercise. The CCP’s 20th national congress, due towards the end of the year, will be the other headline-grabber. President Xi Jinping is hoping to secure an unprecedented third five-year term, which, if achieved, would confirm his position as China’s most powerful leader since Mao Zedong. There will also be jostling for senior positions in the Politburo and Politburo standing committee. It will not necessarily all go Xi’s way. Western analysts differ sharply over how secure Xi’s position truly is. A slowing economy, a debt crisis, an ageing population, huge environmental and climate-related challenges, and US-led attempts to “contain” China by signing up neighbouring countries are all putting pressure on Xi. Yet, as matters stand, 2022 is likely to see ongoing, bullish attempts to expand China’s global economic and geopolitical influence.
a2_text:
Turkey is important in 2022. The President of Turkey is Recep Tayyip Erdoğan. He has a lot of power. His party, AKP, has been in power for 20 years.

Erdoğan is becoming more strict in Turkey. His foreign policy is strong. He has problems with the EU and the US. He works with Russia sometimes about Syria. The economy in Turkey is not doing well. This could cause problems.

Lebanon is another important place. It is close to becoming a failed state. This is like Yemen, where there is a war. Libya is also chaotic.

Palestine is also important. The president, Mahmoud Abbas, is not popular. He stopped the elections. Israeli people are taking land in the West Bank. There is no peace process. These are big problems.

Asia is also important. People will watch China. This will happen at the start and end of the year. Maybe even in the middle of the year too.

The Winter Olympics are in Beijing in February. People want to see who wins the most medals. But some countries will not send officials. This is because they do not like China's human rights problems. These countries include the US and the UK. They think China will use the Olympics for propaganda.

The Chinese Communist Party (CCP) will have a big meeting at the end of the year. This is the 20th national congress. President Xi Jinping wants to stay in power for five more years. This would be his third time. If this happens, he will be the most powerful leader since Mao Zedong.

People will also try to get important jobs in the CCP. But Xi Jinping may not get everything he wants.

Some people think Xi Jinping is very strong. Other people think he is not so strong. China's economy is slowing down. China has a lot of debt. The population is getting older. There are problems with the environment and climate change. The US is trying to stop China by working with other countries. This puts pressure on Xi Jinping.

But in 2022, China will likely try to grow its power around the world. This includes its economy and its influence in other countries.

text: A military attack on Taiwan, which Xi has vowed to re-conquer by any or all means, could change everything. India, China’s biggest regional competitor, may continue to punch below its weight on the world stage. In what could be a symbolically important moment, its total population could soon match or exceed China’s 1.41 billion, according to some estimates. Yet at the same time, Indian birth rates and average family sizes are falling. Not so symbolic, and more dangerous, are unresolved Himalayan border disputes between these two giant neighbours, which led to violence in 2020-21 and reflect a broader deterioration in bilateral relations. The popularity of Narendra Modi, India’s authoritarian prime minister, has taken a dive of late, due to the pandemic and a sluggish economy. He was forced into an embarrassing U-turn on farm “reform” and is accused of using terrorism laws to silence critics. His BJP party will try to regain lost ground in a string of state elections in 2022. Modi’s policy of stronger ties with the west, exemplified by the Quad alliance (India, the US, Japan, Australia), will likely be reinforced, adding to China’s discomfort. Elsewhere in Asia, violent repression in Myanmar and the desperate plight of the Afghan people following the Taliban takeover will likely provoke more western hand-wringing than concrete action. Afghanistan totters on the brink of disaster. “We’re looking at 23 million people marching towards starvation,” says David Beasley of the World Food Programme. “The next six months are going to be catastrophic.” North Korea’s nuclear brinkmanship may bring a showdown as Kim Jong-un’s paranoid regime sends mixed signals about war and peace. The Philippines will elect a new president; the foul-mouthed incumbent, Rodrigo Duterte, is limited to a single term. Unfortunately this is not the case with Scott Morrison, who will seek re-election as Australia’s prime minister.
a2_text:
A war with Taiwan could change everything. China wants to take Taiwan back. China might use force to do this.

India is China’s big competitor. India is growing. Soon, India might have as many people as China. China and India both have about 1.4 billion people. But Indian families are getting smaller.

China and India have problems with their border in the mountains. They fought in 2020 and 2021. This shows that they do not have good relations.

Narendra Modi is the leader of India. He is not as popular as before. The pandemic and the economy are problems. People did not like his new rules for farms. Some say he uses laws against terrorists to stop people from speaking against him. His political party will try to win votes in 2022.

Modi wants India to be friends with the West. He works with the US, Japan, and Australia. This makes China unhappy.

In Myanmar, the government is hurting people. In Afghanistan, the Taliban took over. People are suffering. The West is worried, but might not do much to help. Afghanistan is in a very bad situation.

The World Food Programme says that many people in Afghanistan are starving. The next six months will be very difficult.

North Korea has nuclear weapons. Its leader, Kim Jong-un, is acting dangerously. He sends confusing messages about war and peace. This could cause a big problem.

The Philippines will have a new leader. The current leader can't run again.

The leader of Australia, Scott Morrison, wants to be leader again.

text: Europe It will be a critical year for Europe as the EU and national leaders grapple with tense internal and external divisions, the social and economic impact of the unending pandemic, migration and the newly reinforced challenges, post-Cop26, posed by net zero emissions targets. More fundamentally, Europe must decide whether it wants to be taken seriously as a global actor, or will surrender its international influence to China, the US and malign regimes such as Vladimir Putin’s Russia. The tone may be set by spring elections in France and Hungary, where rightwing populist forces are again pushing divisive agendas. Viktor Orbán, the authoritarian Hungarian leader who has made a mockery of the EU over rule of law, democracy and free speech issues, will face a united opposition for the first time. His fate will be watched closely in Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovenia and other EU member states where reactionary far-right parties flourish. Emmanuel Macron, the neo-Gaullist centrist who came from nowhere in 2017, will ask French voters for a second term in preference to his avowedly racist, Islamophobic rivals, Marine Le Pen and Éric Zemmour. Polls put him ahead, although he also faces what could be a strong challenge from the centre-right Republicans, whose candidate, Valérie Pécresse, is the first woman to lead the conservatives. With the left in disarray, the election could radicalise France in reactionary ways. Elections are also due in Sweden, Serbia and Austria. Germany’s new SPD-led coalition government will come under close scrutiny as it attempts to do things differently after the long years of Angela Merkel’s reign. Despite some conciliatory pledges, friction will be hard to avoid with the European Commission, led by Merkel ally Ursula von der Leyen, and with France and other southern EU members over budgetary policy and debt. France assumes the EU presidency in January and Macron will try to advance his ideas about common defence and security policy – what he calls “strategic autonomy”. Macron’s belief that Europe must stand up for itself in a hostile world will be put to the test on a range of fronts, notably Ukraine.
a2_text:
Europe in the next year will be very important. The EU leaders must deal with problems inside and outside of Europe.

The pandemic is still here. It makes life hard for people and the economy. There are also problems with people moving to Europe.

After the COP26 meeting, countries want to stop using fossil fuels. This is also a challenge.

Europe needs to decide what it wants to be. Does it want to be a strong leader in the world? Or will it let China, the US, and Russia have more power?

The elections in France and Hungary will be important. They may show what will happen in Europe.

In Hungary, Viktor Orbán is the leader. He does not follow the rules of the EU about law, freedom, and democracy. He will have a difficult election against many people who don't agree with him. People in Poland, Czech Republic, Slovenia, and other countries are watching this election.

In France, Emmanuel Macron wants to be president again. Marine Le Pen and Éric Zemmour are also running. They have ideas that some people do not like. Macron is doing well in the polls. But Valérie Pécresse, a woman from another party, is also running. The left party is not strong. The election in France could change things a lot.

There will also be elections in Sweden, Serbia, and Austria.

Germany has a new government. People will watch to see how they do things differently after Angela Merkel. The new government may have problems with the EU Commission and with France about money.

France will lead the EU in January. Macron wants to make Europe stronger in defense. He thinks Europe should be able to protect itself.

Macron thinks Europe needs to be strong in the world. He will have to deal with many problems, like the situation in Ukraine.

text: Analysts suggest rising Russian military pressure, including a large border troop build-up and a threat to deploy nuclear missiles, could lead to renewed conflict early in the year as Nato hangs back. Other trigger issues include Belarus’s weaponising of migration (and the continuing absence of a humane pan-European migration policy) and brewing separatist trouble in Bosnia-Herzegovina and the Balkans. The EU is planning a China summit, but there is no consensus over how to balance business and human rights. In isolated, increasingly impoverished Britain, Brexit buyers’ remorse looks certain to intensify. Relations with the US, which takes a dim view of European autonomy but appears ambivalent over Ukraine, may prove tense at times. Nato, its credibility damaged post-Afghanistan, faces a difficult year as it seeks a new secretary-general. Smart money says a woman could get the top job for the first time. The former UK prime minister Theresa May has been mentioned – but the French will not want a Brit. Latin America The struggle to defeat Jair Bolsonaro, Brazil’s notorious rightwing president, in national elections due in October looks set to produce an epic battle with international ramifications. Inside Brazil, Bolsonaro has been widely condemned for his lethally negligent handling of the Covid pandemic. Over half a million Brazilians have died, more than in any country bar the US. Beyond Brazil, Bolsonaro is reviled for his climate change denial and the accelerated destruction of the Amazon rainforest. Opinion polls show that, should he stand, Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, the former president who was jailed and then cleared on corruption charges, would easily beat Bolsonaro. But that assumes a fair fight. Concern is growing that American supporters of Donald Trump are coaching the Bolsonaro camp on how to steal an election or mount a coup to overturn the result, as Trump tried and failed to do in Washington a year ago. Fears grow that Trump-style electoral subversion may find more emulators around the world.
a2_text:
**Russia and NATO**

Some people think Russia might start another war soon. Russia has many soldiers near its border with Ukraine. Russia said it might put nuclear weapons there. NATO countries might not help Ukraine.

Belarus is using people who want to move to Europe as a weapon. They are making it difficult for people to cross the border. Europe does not have a good plan to help these people. There is trouble in Bosnia and other places in the Balkans. Some people there want to separate from their countries.

**China and the EU**

The EU wants to meet with China. They need to decide if business or human rights are more important.

**Britain and the US**

Britain is not doing well after Brexit. Some people think that leaving the EU was a mistake. Britain's relationship with the US might be difficult. The US does not like Europe being independent. The US does not seem sure about what to do with Ukraine.

**NATO's Future**

NATO is having a hard time after what happened in Afghanistan. They need a new leader. Some people think a woman might get the job. Theresa May, who used to be the leader of Britain, could get the job. But France does not want someone from Britain to be the leader.

**Brazil**

Brazil will have elections in October. It will be a big fight. The current leader is Jair Bolsonaro. Many people do not like him.

Bolsonaro did not handle the COVID-19 pandemic well. Many people in Brazil died. Only the US had more deaths. Bolsonaro does not believe in climate change. He is letting people destroy the Amazon rainforest.

Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva used to be the president. He was in jail, but now he is free. People think he will win the election if he runs. But some people are worried that the election might not be fair.

People who support Donald Trump are helping Bolsonaro. They might try to steal the election. They might try to take over the government like Trump tried to do in the US. People worry that others will copy Trump's bad ideas about elections.

text: Surveys in Europe suggest support for rightwing populist-nationalist politicians is waning, but that may not be the case in South America, outside Brazil, and other parts of the developing world in 2022. Populism feeds off the gap between corrupt “elites” and so-called “ordinary people”, and in many poorer countries, that gap, measured in wealth and power, is growing. In Cuba, Nicaragua, Haiti and Venezuela, supposed champions of the people have become their oppressors, and this phenomenon looks set to continue. In Chile, the presidential election’s first round produced strong support for José Antonio Kast, a hard-right Pinochet apologist, though he was ultimately defeated by Gabriel Boric, a leftist former student leader, who will become the country’s youngest leader after storming to a resounding victory in a run-off. Argentina’s president, Alberto Fernández, faces a different kind of problem in what looks like a tough year ahead, after elections in which his Peronists, one of the world’s oldest populist parties, lost their majority in Congress for the first time in nearly 40 years. Mexico’s president, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, will face ongoing tensions with the US over trade, drugs and migration from Central America. But at least he no longer has to put up with Trump’s insults – for now. North America All eyes will be on the campaign for November’s mid-term elections when the Democrats will attempt to fend off a Republican bid to re-take control of the Senate and House of Representatives. The results will inevitably be viewed as a referendum on Joe Biden’s presidency. If the GOP does well in the battleground states, Donald Trump – who still falsely claims to have won the 2020 election – will almost certainly decide to run for a second term in 2024. Certain issues will have nationwide resonance: in particular, progress (or otherwise) in stemming the pandemic and ongoing anti-vax resistance; the economy, with prices and interest rates set to rise; and divisive social issues such as migration, race and abortion rights, with the supreme court predicted to overrule or seriously weaken provisions of the landmark 1973 Roe v Wade decision.
a2_text:
In Europe, some people think that right-wing politicians are becoming less popular. But this may not be true in South America, except for Brazil. It may also not be true in other poor countries in 2022.

Populism is strong when there is a big difference between rich and powerful leaders and normal people. In many poor countries, this difference is getting bigger.

In Cuba, Nicaragua, Haiti, and Venezuela, leaders who said they would help the people have become bad rulers. This situation might continue.

In Chile, there was a presidential election. José Antonio Kast, a very right-wing politician, got a lot of votes in the first part of the election. He liked Pinochet, a former leader. But he lost to Gabriel Boric. Boric is a young, left-wing leader. He won the election and will be the youngest leader of Chile.

Argentina's president, Alberto Fernández, has problems. His political party, the Peronists, lost their majority in the Congress. This is the first time in 40 years. It looks like a hard year for him.

Mexico's president, Andrés Manuel López Obrador, will have problems with the United States. These problems are about trade, drugs, and people moving from Central America. But he does not have to deal with Trump's bad words anymore, for now.

In North America, everyone is watching the elections in November. The Democrats want to keep control of the Senate and House of Representatives. The Republicans want to win them back.

The results of the elections will show what people think about Joe Biden, the president. If the Republicans do well, Donald Trump might run for president again in 2024. He still says he won the election in 2020, but that is not true.

Some important issues are:

*   The COVID-19 virus and if it is getting better. Some people do not want to get the vaccine.
*   The economy. Prices and interest rates might go up.
*   Social issues like people moving to the country, race, and abortion. The Supreme Court might change the Roe v Wade decision about abortion. This is a very important decision from 1973.

text: The Democrats’ biggest problem in 2022 may be internal party divisions. The split between so-called progressives and moderates, especially in the Senate, undermined Biden’s signature social care and infrastructure spending bills, which were watered down. Some of the focus will be on Biden himself: whether he will run again in 2024, his age (he will be 80 in November), his mental agility and his ability to deliver his agenda. His mid-December minus-7 approval rating may prove hard to turn around. Also under the microscope is Kamala Harris, the vice-president, who is said to be unsettled and under-performing – at least by those with an interest is destabilising the White House. Pete Buttigieg, the transportation secretary who sought the Democratic nomination in 2020, is a man to watch, as a possible replacement for Harris or even for Biden, should the president settle for one term. Concern has grown, meanwhile, over whether the mid-terms will be free and fair, given extraordinary efforts by Republican state legislators to make it harder to vote and even harder for opponents to win gerrymandered congressional districts and precincts with in-built GOP majorities. One survey estimates Republicans will flip at least five House seats thanks to redrawn, absurdly distorted voting maps. This could be enough to assure a Republican House majority before voting even begins. Pressure from would-be Central American migrants on the southern US border will likely be a running story in 2022 – a problem Harris, who was tasked with dealing with it, has fumbled so far. She and Biden are accused of continuing Trump’s harsh policies. Belief in Biden’s competence has also been undermined by the chaotic Afghan withdrawal, which felt to many like a Vietnam-scale humiliation. Another big foreign policy setback or overseas conflagration – such as a Russian land-grab in Ukraine, direct Chinese aggression against Taiwan or an Israel-Iran conflict – has potential to suck in US forces and wreck Biden’s presidency. In Canada, Prime Minister Justin Trudeau is expected to push new policy initiatives on affordable childcare and housing after winning re-election in September.
a2_text:
The Democrats have a big problem. They have groups inside the party that do not agree. Some are called progressives, and some are called moderates. They argue a lot, especially in the Senate.

This fighting made it hard for President Biden to pass laws. He wanted to spend money on social care and roads. But the laws were changed because of the fighting.

People are watching President Biden. He will be 80 years old soon. They wonder if he will run for president again in 2024. They also wonder if he is able to do his job well. Many people do not like the job he is doing now. It may be hard for him to get more people to like him.

Kamala Harris is the Vice-President. People are also watching her. Some people say she is not doing a good job. They say she is not happy in her job. Maybe these people want to make problems for the President.

Pete Buttigieg is important too. He is in charge of transportation. He wanted to be president in 2020. People think he could replace Kamala Harris. He could even replace President Biden if Biden only stays for one term.

People are worried about the elections. The elections are called "mid-terms." Some Republicans are trying to make it harder for people to vote. They are also drawing maps that help Republicans win.

One study says Republicans will win at least five more seats in the House. This is because of the new maps. This could give the Republicans control of the House before the voting even starts.

Many people from Central America want to come to the United States. They are at the border with Mexico. This will be a big problem in 2022. Kamala Harris is in charge of this problem. But some people say she is not doing a good job. People say she and Biden are doing the same bad things that Trump did.

People do not trust President Biden as much now. This is because of what happened in Afghanistan. Many people thought it was a very bad and embarrassing situation.

If something bad happens in another country, it could hurt President Biden. For example, if Russia takes land in Ukraine, that would be bad. If China attacks Taiwan, that would be bad. If Israel and Iran fight, that would be bad. These things could make the US get involved and make things bad for Biden.

In Canada, Justin Trudeau is the Prime Minister. He wants to make new laws about childcare and houses. He wants to make them more affordable. He won the election in September.

text: But in 2021’s snap election his Liberals attracted the smallest share of the popular vote of any winning party in history, suggesting the Trudeau magic is wearing thin. Disputes swirl over alleged corruption, pandemic management, trade with the US and carbon reduction policy. Africa As befits this giant continent, some of 2022’s biggest themes will play out across Africa. Among the most striking is the fraught question of whether Africans, still largely unvaccinated, will pay a huge, avoidable price for the developed world’s monopolising of vaccines, its reluctance to distribute surpluses and share patents – and from the pandemic’s myriad, knock-on health and economic impacts. This question in turn raises another: will such selfishness rebound on the wealthy north, as former UK prime minister Gordon Brown has repeatedly warned? The sudden spread of Omicron, first identified in South Africa, suggests more Covid variants could emerge in 2022. Yet once again, the response of developed countries may be to focus on domestic protection, not international cooperation. The course of the global pandemic in 2022 – both in terms of the threat to health and economic prosperity – is ultimately unknowable. But in many African countries, with relatively young populations less vulnerable to severe Covid harms, the bigger problem may be the negative impact on management of other diseases. It’s estimated 25 million people in Africa will live with HIV-Aids in 2022. Malaria claims almost 400,000 lives in a typical year. Treatment of these diseases, and others such as TB and diabetes, may deteriorate further as a result of Covid-related strains on healthcare systems. Replacing the Middle East, Africa has become the new ground zero for international terrorism, at least in the view of many analysts. This trend looks set to continue in 2022. The countries of the Sahel, in particular, have seen an upsurge of radical Islamist groups, mostly home-grown, yet often professing allegiance to global networks such as al-Qaida and Islamic State. Western efforts to counter this upsurge in jihadist violence may become more organised in 2022.
a2_text:

There are problems with Trudeau. Some people say there is corruption. People disagree about how he handled the pandemic. There are also problems with trade with the US. And people disagree about rules about carbon.

Omicron started in South Africa. More new kinds of Covid might come in 2022. Rich countries might try to protect themselves first. They might not help other countries.

Many people in Africa are young. They might not get very sick from Covid. But Covid might make other health problems worse.
